data.title: Update Markdown Preview on External File changes
data.body:
**Bug**
Issue #5687 - Markdown preview does not update when a markdown file is changed outside of VSCode.

**Fix**
Add filesystem watch to update the markdown preview when the file changes on the system.

![sep-13-2016 17-10-10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18495780/62a7faf0-79d5-11e6-91ff-060badb7c8b1.gif)

Closes #5687

data.title: cmd-shift-left/right triggers focusRightEditor warning

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  1.5.2
- OS Version:
  OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Put your cursor in middle of text. Hit cmd-shift-left or cmd-shift-right with the intention of selecting it. This triggers the error: Command workbench.action.focusLeftEditor has been removed. You can use workbench.action.focusPreviousGroup instead

This is system-wide OS X default keybinding (I just realized how much I use now that it's broken). It even works in this textarea as I type this.

data.title: Fix Markdown Preview Code in Header Font Size
data.body:
**Bug**
Issue #1121 In Markdown preview, code blocks in headers are the wrong font size.

**Fix**
Specify that code blocks in headers should inherit their font-size, instead of brining their own.

![screen shot 2016-09-13 at 3 09 19 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18493520/d67026fc-79c5-11e6-8ed9-a58415fe2aa0.png)

Closes #1121

data.title: Extension Contributions Languages section should show language id
data.body:
Currently under Languages only the Name (first alias) and File Extensions are shown.  We should include the language id since this is useful for users.  For example there are several user settings (ex. files.associations) that require the language id.
This is especially important for language ids that aren't just lowercasing of the language name, for example "C#" -> "csharp". It also makes clear to the user that the language id is not simply the file extensions ("Markdown" is not "md" but "markdown").

data.title: Open recent fsproj file results in window hanging

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Anniversary edition

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create F# project in visual studio 2015
   1.5... 
2. Open source folder in visual studio code
3. Open fsproj file
4. Restart VS code
5. On restart when fsproj is loaded into editor the VS window hangs. File, Edit, View, Go, Help menu still works. Cursor changes to hand above the hanging window, but I'm able to open new window through File -> New Window.

p.s. This doesn't happen on the flesh fsproj file created by Visual Studio 2015. But when I opened with a project I've worked for a little bit, it hangs.

Any advise on how to fix this or diagnose what's causing window to freeze?

data.title: Add shellArgs. Fix #10917
Request: option for find/nextMatchFindAction to search forward only, previousMatchFindAction to search backward only

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Position cursor near bottom of a file.
2. Press <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>f</kbd> and search for something that is before the cursor.
3. Cursor jumps "backwards" and finds term before original cursor position - this is counterintuitive (so "next" means "before"?).

This request is to have an option to have `actions.find` and `editor.action.nextMatchFindAction` to search forward in the file only. If no more matches, do not reposition cursor and inform user no more matches (just like if search term is not found in the file at all).

Included in this option would be to have `editor.action.previousMatchFindAction` to search backward in the file only. If no previous matches, do not reposition cursor and inform user no previous matches.

This should also apply to other actions such as `editor.action.addSelectionToNextFindMatch`, `editor.action.addSelectionToPreviousFindMatch`, etc.

data.title: Support dark theme in Gnome

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5
- OS Version: Linux

I do use light theme on my linux distribution, but in VScode i prefer standard dark theme for editor, so i desired to try to change a gtk theme for single window as i do often with several applications modifying their launchers and .desktop files, and had no success. As i figured out VScode doesn't use gtk for window decorations, so i tried xprop to change theme variant to dark. What i got is that window decoration changed to dark, but menu is still using old light style.

It would be great if VScode will start to use CSD (client side decorations) like in most native and not native gnome apps, so i request this feature too

Steps to Reproduce:
0. Use light gtk theme, that support dark variant, like Arc-GTK
1. Type in terminal: xprop -f _GTK_THEME_VARIANT 8u -set _GTK_THEME_VARIANT "dark"
2. Click VScode window
3. Notice that decorations turned to dark, but menu is still light
3. Cry.

data.title: Mistranslation of "Open Editors" in all locales
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Code in a project directory with a non-English locale like Spanish: `code . --locale=es`

In the file explorer sidebar, the translation string for "open editors" refers to the verb "open," i.e. the action of opening editors, rather than the adjective referring to the state, i.e. "these are the currently open editors." In English the verb and the adjective versions are the same, but in most other languages they're not.

For example in Spanish, the string is "abrir editores" (referring to the action), but it should be "editores abiertos" (referring to the current state). From my limited knowledge of French and other romance languages, it looks to be incorrect across all locales.

![captura de pantalla 2016-09-13 a las 12 56 37](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3317632/18489257/af84f978-79b1-11e6-9051-91af0c63780f.png)
Incorrect translation of "open editors" as "abrir editores"

![captura de pantalla 2016-09-13 a las 12 57 21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3317632/18489286/ca52b9e8-79b1-11e6-8721-28cac23bd857.png)
Translated correctly in a different part of the UI

data.title: Display language identifier in Language Mode drop down
data.body:
Many user settings need to know a language's language id. Examples include files.associations, emmet.syntaxProfiles, emmet.excludeLanguages. Some settings display the language id list in suggestions (ex. files.associations) but not others (ex. emmet.syntaxProfiles).
vscode-docs issue https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs/issues/572 recommends documenting the most commonly used language ids but this list will be long and need to be maintained.
We could display the language id in the Language Mode drop down list. Perhaps in parentheses:
JavaScript (javascript)
C++ (cpp)
The "languages" message on the upper right of the dropdown could be changed to something like "languages (language identifier)" or expand to a full description of language ids.
This way the list will be scoped to only languages the user has installed and always up to date. The list will also be discoverable in the product and not require the user to search our doc website

data.title: MarkerService and ProblemsView do not scale well and block UI thread
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Tested Windows 10 and macOS 10.11

Repro steps:
1. Clone https://github.com/DustinCampbell/diagnostic-perf-test
2. Open the diagnostic-perf-test project in VS Code
3. F5 to compile and launch the extension under the debugger
4. In the debuggee process, select `View->Problems` to display the Problems pane.
5. In the debuggee process, select `View->Command Palette...` and execute the `Populate Diagnostics` command.

At this point, the VS Code debuggee window will stop responding as it populates a single diagnostic for 2000 files. This is very similar to the diagnostics produced for a medium- to large-sized C# solution (say, one generated by Unity) where there are a couple thousand files and each has a single "remove unnecessary using directives" diagnostic.

Expected result:
- Populating diagnostics should not scale exponentially by the number of files.
- Calling `DiagnosticCollection.set(...)` should periodically free up the UI thread while processing.

data.title: [Proposal] Keyboard shortcut to duplicate a line
data.body:
This would be quite convenient if we could duplicate a line with a single shortcut, since it is quite a  common practice when coding to reuse a previous line. This quite simple proposal may help to bring some productivity.
## Overview of the workflow

When the cursor is on a line, the current line, we could imagine to be able to duplicate the current line by pressing a shortcut. In _Notepad++_ it is CTRL+D. It seems this key combination is still available in VS Code so we could use it as a shortcut to duplicate lines.

Also, it could be convenient to have this command in the _Edition_ menu, maybe between the copy/paste related commands and the search/replace commands.

data.title: Keyboard shortcut editor.action.selectHighlights selects only first 999 matches

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a file with more than 999 examples of a text string (e.g. 2,000 lines containing "This is a line").
2. Highlight a word or phrase, and to highlight all matches, press ctrl+shift+l (or whatever editor.action.selectHighlights has been mapped to).

Only the first 999 matches will be selected. This is a problem when working with large files.

data.title: Terminal - Cannot read property 'className' of undefined
data.body:
I've seen this a couple times now, and when it shows up, I can't open the terminal until I restart Code. I can't get devtools to load sourcemaps, though. It looks like the undefined element is `this.wrapperElement` in `setVisible`. 

```
Cannot read property 'className' of undefined: TypeError: Cannot read property 'className' of undefined
    at g (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:40:23049)
    at Object.b [as toggleClass] (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:40:23693)
    at t.setVisible (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:124:1799)
    at file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:124:7359
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at e.setActiveInstanceByIndex (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:124:7335)
    at e.createInstance (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:124:6205)
    at t.run (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:89:7797)
    at file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:95:3877
    at n.Class.define.then (file:////Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:31:11045)
```

data.title: Debug an already running task
data.body:
**Feature Request**

As described in this[ SO question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/38871062/visual-studio-code-tasks-debugging), start a task in debug mode and allow the debugger to connect to a running task. 

Specific scenario this would help with - Task to run unit tests then debug an errant unit test.
